III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Development of service plans
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418
Section (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents and the
Description foster parents in the development of service plans to enable the
parent or parents and foster parents to understand the plan for the
child and the parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to
and review the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or
parents and foster parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the child and the
child's family is confidential.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care worker has not assisted parent with reunification.
Investigation Complainant was contacted by email on 5/6/24 and did not have
any additional information to provide.
Chief Administrator was interviewed by phone on 5/8/24. Chief
Administrator reported the foster care case was moving toward
termination. The case had been open for about two years and
recently had new allegations under investigation by DHHS. Due to
the new allegations, court suspended unsupervised parenting time
and ordered that parenting time occur supervised at the agency.
Chief Administrator was not aware of any complaints or concerns
from the parents regarding their caseworker or a lack of support.
Chief Administrator had not received any grievances from either
parent.
Parent 1 was interviewed by phone on 5/8/24. Parent 1 stated she
felt her worker was not being helpful with reunification and the
court recently set a date for a termination hearing. Parent 1
reported she did everything that was asked of her, but Worker 1
only focuses on termination, not reunification. Parent 1 expressed
frustration about parenting time moving from unsupervised to
supervised. However, she understood there was an open
investigation and the court order needed to be followed. Parent 1
reported that Parent 2 never had unsupervised visits, and believed
the agency did not like Parent 2. Parent 1 stated there was an
incident where Parent 2 was frustrated and yelled at agency staff
2

in court. Parent 1 felt the agency did not work well with Parent 2
after that. Parent 1 provided contact information for Parent 2.
Parent 1 stated she wanted a better worker. Earlier in the case,
there was a “better” worker assigned, but she left the agency.
After that, Worker 2 was assigned for about a year. During that
time, Worker 2 and Parent 2 had disagreements. Parent 1 did not
provide additional detail but stated Parent 2 may want to discuss
it. Parent 1 noted that Worker 1 was assigned to their case in
October 2023. Parent 1 stated that she did not feel Worker 2
should be involved in their case any longer. However, she
believed Worker 1 and Worker 2 discuss their case together.
Overall, Parent 1 felt that Worker 1 did not do enough to help her.
When asked what she felt Worker 1 should be doing differently,
Parent 1 indicated she felt Worker 1 should focus on returning the
children, not terminating rights. Parent 1 could not identify any
services or referrals that were needed from Worker 1. Parent 1
stated she also felt that Supervisor 1 was “out to get them”. Parent
1 was asked what specifically Supervisor 1 did or said that made
her feel that way. Parent 1 said she did not know and did not have
any examples to provide. Although, Parent 1 recalled asking
Supervisor 1 for a new case worker and did not receive a
response.
Worker 1 was interviewed by video conference on 5/10/24.
Worker 1 reported she was assigned to the case in October 2023.
The kids had a few unsupervised, overnight visits with Parent 1.
However, there were two allegations reported to DHHS during
those visits. The DHHS investigations have impacted the
reunification process. In January 2024 there was a goal change to
adoption. Worker 1 noted she encouraged the parents to
participate in services, leading up to the next court hearing in June
2024. The services the parents were referred to included
parenting classes, individual counseling, domestic violence
counseling, and couples counseling. Worker 1 stated Parent 1 had
completed four parenting classes previously. However, it was
difficult to show she had benefited from the classes when there
were two DHHS allegations during unsupervised parenting time.
Worker 1 reported Parent 2 had started counseling but had not
completed any other services. Worker 1 verified that parenting
time had changed due to the recent allegations under
investigation. Worker 1 could not recall requests by either parent
for services that were not already in place.
Supervisor 1 was scheduled for a video conference interview on
5/10/24. However, the supervisor was a no-show. On 5/23/24,
3

Supervisor 1 ended their employment with the agency, without
responding to emailed questions from DCWL.
Program Manager was interviewed by video conference on
5/10/24. Program Manager verified there is a current DHHS
investigation open regarding Parent 1 & 2, which is why parenting
time was moved to supervised. Program Manager stated that
termination has been a possibility for a while, due to a lack of
progress with the parents and the length of time the case has
been open. Program Manager reported she had never received a
grievance or complaint from either parent about Worker 1.
Worker 2 was interviewed by phone on 5/24/24. Worker 2
reported she was the case worker for a year and a half. The
children were originally returned home to Parent 1 in October
2022, but reentered care due to allegations reported to DHHS.
About two months later, Parent 2 was doing very well with their
treatment plan and a plan was made to move to unsupervised
visits. However, Parent 2 became angry during a court hearing
and made threats toward Worker 2. Since that time, Parent 2
refused to participate in counseling or services to address his
anger issues, or domestic violence. In addition to needing
counseling, Parent 2 also needed stable housing. Despite these
needs, Worker 2 reported progress as Parent 2 completed some
parenting classes and had improved his parenting skills.
Regarding Parent 1, parenting classes have been completed.
Along with participation in counseling and completion of a home
assessment. However, there are still safety concerns regarding
reunification. Including the open DHHS investigation and both
parent’s refusal to comply with drug screens.
When asked about Parent 1’s concern about Worker 2 still being
involved in the case while not assigned, Worker 2 explained that
she has been subpoenaed for the termination hearing in June.
Therefore, Worker 2 has kept up to date with information, but has
not been actively involved in the case management.
Parent 2 was interviewed by phone on 5/31/24. Parent 2
expressed frustration with the agency, stating they make
professional decisions based on personal feelings and not case
facts. Parent 2 reported he and Worker 2 had problems in the
past. Parent 2 felt that due to Worker 1 training under Worker 2,
she was bias to their case from the beginning. Parent 2 reported
he felt both caseworkers focused on the wrong information in
court and the judge did not listen to the positive things the parents
had done. When asked if Parent 2 had spoken with his attorney
4

about these concerns and provided them with information to
present in court, Parent 2 stated his attorney had not been helpful.
Parent 2 reported there were no referrals or services needed from
the agency at this time. Parent 2 stated he had completed all of
the services, including parenting classes and counseling. Parent
2’s frustration was overall due to feeling the agency was bias and
did not want to return the children, despite the parent’s attempts to
complete services. Parent 2 stated throughout the case, he felt
that reunification was within reach, but then a new investigation
would occur with DHHS, causing another delay. This occurred
three times. Parent 2 reported he wanted a new case worker that
would not be bias. Parent 2 was recently informed by the agency
that a new worker has been assigned.
Documents reviewed:
• Service plans and Parent/Agency Treatment plans were
reviewed. The documentation supported the information
provided by Worker 1 & Worker 2 regarding progress with
services for Parent 1 & Parent 2.
• Per MiSACWIS, a DHHS investigation was opened on
4/19/24 regarding Parent 1 and Parent 2.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as Parent 1 and Parent 2 did
not identify any specific actions they felt the agency failed to
complete to support reunification. Through a review of the case
file, it appeared the agency provided services as required and
kept the parents informed of necessary treatment plan information
and referrals.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
